reviewText: In some ways, this game is the perfect metaphor for our lives. Each of us is the little spacecraft and we chase after the light of our dreams. There will be several paths for us to try out on our journey, with the shadow of our doubts slowing us down if we let it. We will inevitably crash and burn many... many times into obstacles that came out of ♥♥♥♥ing nowhere and there will be that one stage that will seem impossible. However, if we have the courage to press that 'retry' button, then eventually we will beat the game. Just remember to never lose sight of your dream, and don't let the sun set on you before you get to the end.\n\nPraise the sun. 10/10

reviewText: It's like a crazy minimalist hybrid of Star Fox/F-Zero crossed with Super Hexagon's speed and reflex driven twitch aspects.  My only real complaints are the bugs at the moment with achievements and some other stuff.  I liked the older leaderboard stle they had in previous versions, and the soundtrack could be a lot better and perfect the experience.  Overall, great game and I'd highly recommend it if you're into this sort of thing.  Has great level editing tools as well as what will be a great user-created level portal.  I'm not a fan of luck-based" procedural generated levels but hopefully that can be eliminated by user-created levels at some point.  I'd also like a static leaderboard alongside the daily leaderboard
date: for best players overall.  And hopefully in time all of this can be worked out in some way.\n\nBut yeah
hoursPlayed: one of the best indie titles to release on Steam recently and worth the time and money."

reviewText:
Race the Sun is an impressive test of your reflexes & concentration skills reminiscent of classic forward-scrolling 3D shooters like Star Fox. Before the sun disappears, your solar craft must make it as far as possible without hitting anything. At the same time, trying to stay in the light & grab as many power-ups, tris or wormholes across the landscape, to boost you along as fast as possible. There's a fantastic sense of speed building up the longer you survive, often flying past objects so close you could touch it (and sometimes mistakenly do lol!).

Lighting effects of the sun streaming rays of light through the various shapes of the artifically inspired worlds looks awesome, while also being a key mechanic functionally in the game design!

The world is randomly regenerated every 24hrs to provide new challenging combinations, plus in-between there is plenty of community maps to try on the Workshop. There are also specific challenges to level-up & upgrade your default craft to work towards longer term.  Some of these are really hard!

Great to play on the big screen (in your lounge room), for a brief daily distraction (since games can be very quick indeed sometimes) :) or even a longer session where you reach for the clouds & conquer your (or friends) high scores! There are some tough achievements & a game plus mode for the hardcore out there.

Race the Sun is easy to pick up but hard to put down... while always striving for that elusive 'high score' just over the horizon!

Menus are a bit strange to navigate with a controller & the bright white tones can overwhelm, but other than these minor factors, this is a top quality & very addictive little indie title!


If you enjoyed reading this review, please follow True Blue Reviews for more recommendations!

reviewText:
Race the Sun is a very nice little game to play when you have nothing to do with yourself.

It's very easy to learn, but like most things, a bit more difficult to master. You have to get as far as you can along the map, while avoiding deadly obstacals, before the sun goes down. While trying to get the highest score you can, you can pick up boosters that will temporarily stop the sun's slow descent.

There are four different maps that you can play on. You start with the first one and can unlock the second and third ones by leveling up. If you want the fourth, you have to buy it. I have played and enjoyed the first three, but I haven't tried out the last one. All of the maps randomize every 24 hours, so the layout is slightly different each day.

I play my own music when gaming, but the soundtrack for Race the Sun is something I wouldn't mind listening to. And if you don't enjoy it, there is always the mute button.

In the end, I would recommend it to anybody who is thinking about buying it.

reviewText:
Overview: Arcade Racer focused on avoiding obstacles

The Good:

+The game goes on forever, the goal is not only how far you can go but how many points you can get. The premise is that your ship is solar powered, thus staying in the sunlight keeps you going. The sun slowly goes down creating more shadows.  Powerups can extend your time.

+ Every 24 hours the course is reset. Everything is randomized to a degree forcing you to rely more on skill and luck rather than memorization

+ The game gives you a multiple objectives to complete. After completing them your ship gets upgraded.

+VERY addicting, the game has the just one more time" feeling to it.

+Steamworkshop is intregrated very nicely with a variety of different maps to try out.

+The game has a unique and simplistic artstyle to it. As the sun sets it creates a really nice setting. After playing some of the user generated maps you really see some of the verstatily of the engine and graphics despite how simple it is.

+Hard mode to really test you to the limit....if you find the main game to easy.

The Bad:

-  You will get frustrated....a lot.

Conclusion

This is a really fun and simple game was a simple premise and works wonderfully due to the randomness of the world. Its a game you can keep going back to and play in short sessions.
"

reviewText:
Race The Sun is an adrenaline rush the likes of which few other games can compare! The whoosh as you soar past objects, the intensity as the sun threatens to disappear past the horizon, and the unbelievable moments of triumph when you make it through in one piece are but small bits of what makes for an extremely exhilarating experience.

Your goal is simple: pilot a futuristic solar powered flying-craft at breakneck speeds, dodging obstacles and attempting to get as far as you can before the sun inevitably sets. What turns RtS from a simple detraction into an addiction is the execution. Every aspect has an unprecedented level of refinement, from the effortless maneuvering of your vehicle to the expertly placed obstructions which become increasingly complex and challenging the further you progress, show a clear attention to detail and an superb sense of direction by the developers.

Aside from chasing the leaderboards, there are also 25 levels of skill based objectives for you to complete, which unlock upgrades and details to outfit your craft with. It took me about five hours to clear them all, at which point you truly begin your climb up the leaderboards. Although the game does lose a bit of its drive without these challenges to complete, having a newly remixed world every day (complete with daily leaderboards) still gives a reason to keep coming back for more, which is made even easier by how well RtS works as a pickup and play game, while still providing enough depth to make longer sessions just as enjoyable (those looking for an extra challenge will definitely find it in the ultra-hard Apocalypse mode).

Lastly I can't stress enough how unexpectedly amazing the presentation is. The textures themselves might be basic, but there is an elegance in RtS's barren landscape that works amazingly well with how fast you will be soaring through it. The sparse use of color becomes even more important, outlining oncoming obstacles and highlighting power-ups in your peripheral vision that might otherwise be lost to more robust graphical effects. The stark contrast between light and shadow plays a key role in creating a sense of dread whenever you cross into one, letting you know the end is nigh if you don't get out of there fast. A great score and excellent sound effects round out the package, which words really can't do any justice to.

It only took one round for me to get hooked to Race the Sun. Developer Flippfly absolutely nailed it and created something that truly astounded me, perhaps more so than any other game the year it released. I'm just going to end this by saying you need to play this for yourself! It's a breathtaking game that I desperately want to share with others, and one that deserves to be played by a far larger crowd than those who have managed to discover it.

Don't let it slip by you, the sun is already setting.

You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

reviewText:
A peaceful runner-style game where you guide a solar powered craft through an ever more shadowy obstacle course.

From experience of driving towards the sun, you wouldn't think much of a game that focuses on flying towards the sun. Why would I want to do that? The sun is bright and makes my eyes hurt. This game is a fun way to use our imagination, and enjoy ourselves in a solar powered aircraft. If it helps, presume that you are wearing sunglasses, perhaps even fashionable ones. Do you feel cool? Are you prepared to look directly at bright lights? Fantastic.

I imagine this takes place in a sad, dystopic future devoid of fine art or literature, where fossil fuels and other natural resources have been exhausted. All that remains are a few mostly abandoned cities, the wilds between, and due to the political turmoil of resource starvation, the world is on the eve of annihilation.

Enter our protagonist, a strong silent individual. You're transporting yourself and a motley crew of rogues, miscreants, and iconoclast scientists aboard a solar-powered plane last-ditch effort to survive the imminent nuclear annihilation and attempt to prolong the death of a dying world much as a doctor extends the lives of those with chronic diseases. Specifically, you have a technology, a solar powered technology that is also built into your very aircraft. This technology opens portals to new worlds, and any one of them could be the paradise awaiting the future of humanity. Occasionally a bird approaches to aid you on your quest, as if nature itself is encouraging you in  your quest.

Every once in a while you find structure capable of powering these warp gates and moving through them transports you to strange, fanciful, wonderful, and potentially terrible lands. Are any of these places inhabitable? It is unlikely, but any leap into the unknown could eventually show you the future of our species. There is such limited time though. This is certainly the last day before the missiles launch, and that means that when your plane falls to the ground at dusk, the world is lost.

Controls are simple. You turn left, you turn right, you jump when you've got the right power up, and there's also a powerup which allows you to accidentally crash into a wall without dying. Throughout you pick up stars that increase your speed. You may note that speed will keep the sun higher on the horizon for longer periods of time.  You can do a barrel roll as well.

If the sun sets you run out of power and die. If you collide with sufficient force, you die. The difficulty ramps up nicely as well, so that death, which comes to us all, may always be delayed a bit longer. There's a couple of starting levels of differing difficulty, and a workshop with extras, as well as an expansion that I have not tried as of yet.

You level up by doing things like not turning left for a while, or being good at not hitting stuff, or collecting a lot of stuff in the air. These levels give you things like a magnet that makes it so you pick up stuff easier, or a battery that lets you survive in the shadows better. You can also put stickers on your plane, which alone with the portals is the closest thing to visual texture in the game.

This game is grey scale polygons everywhere. Grey pyramids? Probably trees or mountains depending on scale? Grey rectangular prisms I imagine are buildings. There are some that look like shrubbery or boulders. The aesthetic is minimalist and produced a light feeling of ennui. There is quality lighting and shadow, which is fantastic as these are actually used as gameplay mechanics. Different modes have differing color schemes, and the apocalyptic mode is especially pleasant to view.

The sounds are quite nice. The music is of limited quantity, but the quality is apparent and it elicits an appropriate response.

If you have an imagination, or just want something of variable relaxation and pace, something of an original concept, then this could be quite an enjoyable original addition for you. Personally I gave it my full attention for several relaxing enjoyable hours.

This review has been produced in accordance with green technologies, specifically the aeronautical technologies behind solar powered propulsion. These machines are often light weight fully electric craft and represent an important engineering challenge for developing technologies for cleaner, cheaper aircraft. Great game to play every now and then. Really fun and fast paced.
Graphics looks minimalistic with just mostly grey but it is an interesting style and doesn't distract from the action.
The Soundtrack is good but there sadly aren't that many songs. You can buy it here.
Controlls feel very tight.

There are also 4 different mode: Normal (which you will play most of the time)
Apocalypse (when you want more challenge)
Labyrinth (a more slower paced mode,which allows you to have more time to
decide where to go with a small amount of puzzles
Zen Mode (accessable only with the DLC, this is a relaxing mode without any presure or challenge

The levels/world changes every 24h so you have enought time to try to get a high score for the day but also enought divercity so it doesn't get boring that quickly.

There is one DLC which adds the Zen Mode (like already listed above)

Don't let the shadows catch you!
The goal is clear: get as many points as possible and as far as possible without crashing into something or running out of solar power. Easier said then done!

I highly recommend getting this game, even if you don't like arcade-style games, because this one really mixes things up! Challenge!

reviewText:
Race the Sun is a very simple game, your objective is to go as far as you can before the sun when down because your vehicle is powered by the sun and will be destroyed without power. Along the way you find many obstacle here and there to give the game some challenge.

To be honest i didn't know this game is exist before i bought it from humble bundle, and i actually glad that i bought it. This game mechanic along with the graphic and the sound effect is really good and simple. It give you the sense of peace and you rarely get that feeling when you try to play this type of game where your objective is to go as far as you can before dying and the high speed vehicle that you are trying to control feels very epic and futuristic and thats a good thing. The game also give you some simple objective for you to complete like avoid hitting anything in 2 stage or collect this amount of point or jump 5 time in one run or something along those line. In my opinion that objective is really refreshing and it will makes you try the game with a different tactics than usual. If you complete the objective you will level up and you will get many new upgrade for your ship like a magnet to catch all the point near you and all of the other stuff.

Soo the conclusion is this game is really fun and enjoyable to play in your spare time when you are bored, its a good game and the price is not that expensive either. :3 But if you looking for a game with alot of feature sadly this game is not for you, but if you looking for a cool and fun casual game this game is for you !
Recommended ! :3

reviewText: The idea of a minuscule studio putting out a game that will potentially entrance millions with its easy accessibility and well-graduated complexity curve proves that there is still room in the market for the little guy. Race the Sun is not only a fun little addiction but hopefully also a harbinger of the return of boutique developers.If Race The Sun’s tracks remain as consistently well-paced and tiered as the raft of stages we’ve experienced to date, then it can be considered a success rather than an experiment: a confident genre hybrid worthy of your time and patience because who knows, today could be your day.Race the Sun is very close to a perfect pick-up-and-play game, except for the bit where it’s very hard not to keep playing once you’ve started. A quick break easily turns into one more attempt, trying to plot a different course over the cluttered plains, maximizing Tri collection while minimizing the risk of turning into a cloud of debris.An original take on the arcade time-trial formula.Race the Sun is an elegant endeavor, pairing slick action and stiff challenge with systems that make you want to come back day after day.

reviewText: You have probably heard the expression Less is more". And it pretty much applies here because this game is quite simple with minimalistic design. But just because it is that way doesn't mean that you will be able to complete it in few hours or feel that there's something missing. Let me tell you more about it.\n\nLet's start with the story. There is not other way  to put it but to say that there isn't one. Yep
date: it is simple as that. Basically you are piloting a spacecraft fueled by solar energy and the sun is your death timer. And for this game it couldn't have been better. On the bright side you don't need to worry about the story being to complex
recommended: bad or uninteresting. This game is more about highest scores and tense gameplay.\n\nBut let's talk about those simplistic graphics. When I launched the game for the first time it looked boring for few seconds but not much more than that because simple graphics can be good in its own right. In my opinion the game should be fun and engaging first and only then it should be an eye candy. There are of course games that are an eye candy first but we're not talking them right now. The beauty of the game in the arrangement of the obstacles
hoursPlayed: it's in clouds
voteText: in shapes and in the variety of all those things. But we'll talk about those in detail later on.\n\nFor now let's talk gameplay. This being basically a racing game where you
helpfulPercent: uh... race the sun and trying not to let it set involves high speed. You need to be as fast as you can and there are things that make you go faster like boosts and you will have to find those boosts if you don't want to run out of energy. There are other bonuses in the game as well. Jumping for example that can help you avoid certain death. Or the one that is basically an extra life that can be crucial in the later stages of the game. And there are 'tris' that increase your points multiplier. Although you can complete first few stages without too much maneuvering you will have to change your course if you want to find any of these.\nThere are many challenges and achievements too that will push your comprehension of what is possible in this game.\nThe game does no have difficulty settings but it definitely gets harder and harder as you move further from region to region. falling skyscrapers and more.

reviewText:
A MINIMALISTIC Breakdown Rating
PROS
Simple controls.
Minimalistic geometric designs (simple yet elegant).
Quite challenging.
World changes everyday.
Low specifications required (who could ask for more?).
Also available on Google Play and Apple App Store.
CONS
Slippery-like movements (when playing in PC). You totally need a controller (optional).
Kinda dark at some regions and some areas are edgy to drift/turn to another direction.
OVERALL - This game is absolutely simple yet amazing. Worth to buy the game and its DLCs (Sunrise DLC is so awesome).

RATING - 9/10 would find ourselves chasing the sun until sunset.

reviewText:
So...this game.

I like the concept of Race the Sun.  Fly fast, avoid obstacles, keep going!   Pretty simple really.  I don't even mind the bland graphics.  They service the purpose.

You know what I don't like about Race the Sun?  I really suck at it!  That's more from 40 year old crappy reflexes than the game's fault though.

Do you have better reflexes than middle aged man?  You might like it.  I can see the potential in there.   I'd say the $9.99 asking price is a bit steep though.  I got it for $2 or 3  off of Indie Game Stand, so keep your eyes peeled.  It's a good value at it's $3.99 price.

reviewText: The minimalist graphics, sounds, and mechanics contribute a sort of zen quality; relaxing, in a way, while requiring every reflex to be spot-on.  Each region has a distinct visual style, making you want to explore it, but there's no way to go too far off the path, and the repetitive nature within a level makes it hard to remember what comes next.  Upgrades are tied to a series of achievements, some trivial, others frustrating, but always having three current ones makes it fairly easy to climb quickly.\n\nMy children, too, love it, partly for the thrill of seeing a place they've never been able to get to before, and partly for the flashy barrel rolls.  Granted, they die even more often than I do, but that makes it even easier to prefix a request with Okay

reviewText:
Race The Sun is one of those endless runners we've seen hundreds of times before on our mobile phones. But we've rarely seen one appear on Steam. It's because Race The Sun is stylish, fun and addictive, and not necessarily in that order.

You basically steer a ship across a randomly generated world with tons of objects to avoid and power-ups to collect.

It's fast paced and objective based. Well, it's not required, really, but it helps you upgrade your ship later on and might make your life a little easier. There are always 3 random objectives to complete, and with each objective you complete you'll earn 1 (easy objective) to 3 (harder objective) upgrade points. Upgrades can be a higher multiplier right from the start or the ability to store 2 power-ups instead of 1.

While racing you have to collect yellow power-ups to keep raising the sun. Your ship is energy powered and staying in the shadows for too long will slow you down, resulting in a lower score (because, obviously, you can't collect items as quickly anymore). And if the sun goes down it's game over, too.

In the end I was pleasantly surprised by Race The Sun. I grew tired of endless runners a long time ago, but the combination of random worlds, power-ups and objectives make this game feel fresh somehow. Praise the sun !

[Rating: 78/100]

reviewText: Addictive as hell. Minimalist graphics and gameplay, yet what few elements there are, they are done masterfully. It forces you to just relax, pull back a bit, and remember that games should be played in moderation.

reviewText: The game is minimalist and too much can not write about it, but does that mean it is bad? Absolutely!\nWe control a solar-powered plane. Our goal is to fly toward the sun, avoid shadows and do not hit anything. The music is pleasing to the ear and does not irritate, sounds collected bonuses also are ok. The graphics, it's a matter of taste, I like to such minimalism and it speaks to me. To all of this there is very a honey flight model. The plane responds very well to control. The game starts off easy and gradually increasing challenge while giving a lot of laughter and a little bit of gymnastics (some people will curse). To fly millimeters of obstacles, spin bypass two obstacles, or the slipping through narrow gaps will make shout of victory, and in a moment dispersed we pitch on the next object. It's not a production in which you'll soak for hours (although I couldn't tear myself - on the principle one last time") but to turn once and chillout. I strongly recommend it

reviewText:
Race the Sun is a type of forever runner game that has you piloting a flightless hover ship as it glides along a minimalist desert of walls, triangle spikes and blocks that fall over. Your ship is solar powered and going too far into shadows will slow you down and with the sun setting in the horizon itself, that turns the sun into a timer. Slamming into an object is failure, but you can graze an edge of your ship and be fine for a while.

On the surface, there's nothing wrong with the game, its easy to play, left and right to steer and well left and right to steer. It takes a moment for your ship to shift. The controls are simple and work well with a keyboard or 360 controller. You can do things like barrel rolls if you steer too far one way then hard turn it the other way. You can even unlock a single jump and other upgrades for your ship like a magnet that draws in orbs.

The game is shallow and even worse it relies on only one level for the most part. This single level resets itself each day. New day, new level. Other than that, you can unlock two additional levels and even play a credits level that has you flying under the credits in what feels like a flat open space with no challenge rather than an actual level.

Because its just one level, and the game never modifies itself, it makes the game feel like its more about memory than skill. Sure it takes skill to move between two falling blocks, but it takes memory to remember that you can just drive around the wall to a much easier path.

Each level consists of different regions and each region seems to be a loop of itself twice. Well loop with some extras thrown in. As if someone copied and pasted then added some extra fluff. Between each region a white bird will zig-zag and drop four orbs one direction and four orbs another direction. Then it will drop a sun orb which surges your ship to its top speed. You'll find several blue orbs, sun orbs and green jump orbs throughout each level. There are ramps here and there that let you catch big air, falling blocks and shadows to slow you down. The funny thing is you can jump off a ramp high over orbs and it will still collect them if you touch the beam of light over them. Perhaps that's an unlocked feature. Its about as bare bones as it comes to runners.

You'll find portal gates that for whatever reason send you into space where you have a view from the cockpit. The game plays much slower and everything is black. You get to see a galactic space battle in black and white as you fly through it dodging lesser vessels as they zoom by. It feels out of place at best and only makes the game feel a lot easier going so slow. If we're still piloting the same ship when we're in the portal, am I still powered by the sun? Where is the sun in space? I sure can't see the sun.

In the main game itself you can change the camera view from a behind chase cam to a bumper view. Inside the galactic space battle, you're stuck in the cockpit, pressing the camera view button shifts the view by a few pixels. its odd that the game shifts at all when its that small of a difference.

There's a leveling up mechanic that has you accomplishing three goals to get to the next level. Getting to level eleven and twenty-five unlock new levels, but to get there you'll need to do things like jump ten times and do twenty barrel rolls in a single play. The further you go, the more challenging these goals become. Its definitely a way to add some longevity to a shallow game that feels like little to no effort was put in. The entire game feels like no effort was put in and its really the players that need to put time into the game. I want to play here, not work here.

To the game's credit, it looks great. The minimalist approach enhances the game and my enjoyment of it. It makes good use of a dynamic lighting system. The sun casts shadows, although some of the shadows seem to be painted on hazards to hurt your time. Even with a sun, some levels are just gray. Yes indeed, two-hundred and fifty-five shades of gray monochromatic action. Of course a level can be any color, I just seem find gray levels.

Race the Sun has a level editor and Steam workshop integration, so you can always find new levels. I took one look at the level editor, saw how deep it is and then closed it. I've learned so many other level editors that its tough to justify putting time into this one. The real problem is why is that our job as players to make new levels? Sure its fun to create levels, publish them and rate them, but as a developer why are we stuck with one level per day on the computer version of what is essentially a mobile game? That sort of mechanic is what keeps people coming back and sitting through ads day after day and not people that paid money.

Speaking of paying money and mobile ports, on the start screen, they have DLC, the soundtrack and the mobile version to buy. That's understandable, a lot of bigger games, non indie games with shareholders often use this tactic right front and center and fans let them know it. Race the Sun is immune to this and people still manage to love the game for its brief and addictive gameplay. For a game that sells a soundtrack, why is there only one song? This whole game seems like a big cash grab.

There's so little here that its a starvation and so the game keeps you coming back for more with daily courses. You keep coming back to get your moneys worth, to get that quick shallow fix and move on with life knowing that level you spent an hour memorizing and mastering will never appear again. Your work, effort and bragging rights are replaced by tomorrow's level. A chance to wake up and do it all over again.

While I hate to judge a game for everything but the game, there's just not much game here. you go left, you go right, take a ramp. remember what you did wrong. Wash; rinse; repeat.

reviewText: A short, simple, yet very addicting game for every speed demon there is. reviewText:
This game makes hours feel like minutes.
I think that the first region has a good learning curve, you sit back dodge obstables and collect blue items which adds to your multiplier score, yellow adds time and gives you a speed boost, green adds a jump and purple adds a get out of jail free card if you crash.
When i reached the second region i found myself swaying my head side to side when i dodged.
At the third region and beyond i had my controller in a death grip and my face planted against the screen.

It leaves a smile on my face when i pick up an yellow time/boost orb and i loose control of the situation thinking im gonna crash but for some lucky reason i manage to get through.

The world also changes everyday which mix things up a bit and keeps it fresh. You also get tasks to do which raises your level and unlocks abilities for your ship.

reviewText: Race the Sun is a brilliant little endless runner. This is a genre that I often want to like but frequently fail to do so as the execution never quite works for me. But in Race the Sun it does. The 24 hour world resets strike a great balance between getting the chance to practice and perfect something, while always having something new to try each day. Also, unlike the side scrollers in the genre, RtS offers a degree of movement freedom that actually scratches something of an exploration itch in me.

reviewText:
In some ways, this game is the perfect metaphor for our lives. Each of us is the little spacecraft and we chase after the light of our dreams. There will be several paths for us to try out on our journey, with the shadow of our doubts slowing us down if we let it. We will inevitably crash and burn many... many times into obstacles that came out of ♥♥♥♥ing nowhere and there will be that one stage that will seem impossible. However, if we have the courage to press that 'retry' button, then eventually we will beat the game. Just remember to never lose sight of your dream, and don't let the sun set on you before you get to the end.
Great game to play every now and then. Really fun and fast paced.
Graphics looks minimalistic with just mostly grey but it is an interesting style and doesn't distract from the action.
The Soundtrack is good but there sadly aren't that many songs. You can buy it here.
Controlls feel very tight.

There are also 3 different mode:
Normal (which you will play most of the time)
Apocalypse (when you want more challenge)
Labyrinth (a more slower paced mode,which allows you to have more time to
decide where to go with a small amount of puzzles
Zen Mode (accessable only with the DLC, this is a relaxing mode without any presure or challenge

The levels/world changes every 24h so you have enought time to try to get a high score for the day but also enought divercity so it doesn't get boring that quickly.

Overall i think it is a great game for all ages and you should definetly check it out

reviewText:
very good at what it does. if you enjoy dodging at speed - get.

Edit:
After continuing to play each track most days I feel that I can give a better description of your development.

Level generation works like this:
Each region has a number of different setups for each part, so, rather than generating completely new levels, it mixes them up - so while it keeps replayability by changing track, you also improve because you are actually practicing similar courses and learn how to react. The track and scoreboards change every 24 hours.

I tend to get tired of games once I complete or master them, but I continue to enjoy playing this for about 15-30 minutes a day to play the tracks, and with user created levels coming soon it can only become a better deal.

reviewText:
This is such an amazing game! Firt heard of Race the Sun in a text from the developer at Gamasutra and been waiting since then.

You can read about gameplay specifics in further reviews for I'll focus on the experience.

Dynamics is the word here. You can actually feel the wind as you play. Try and make a long curve and you'll know what I'm talking about. The obstacles move in such a crazy way you get vertigo feelings trying to avoid those damn moving blocks!

The soundtrack, simple as it is, provides an immersive experience as you get speed, and the clean background keeps you playing for hours until you realize it's past time to go to sleep.

Buy this game, even if it's not in sale. You won't regret.

reviewText:
I got this game because it was free for a day and had steam cards. After playing it I'm considering buying the DLC.

Mechanically its very straightforward -  you steer a solar powered ship and see how far you can go. As your travel you collect power-ups while trying to avoid the shadows and not crash. If you survive long enough the sun sets and your race ends.

While playing you have three goals to complete in order to level up and unlock more options. Some of these are really annoying (like only turning left), whereas others are simple (like hit X objects). The options vary and can be different game modes or unlocked items to aid your flight.

The track changes each day which makes this an excellent casual play game.

Its also fairly addictive, I frequently found myself thinking Just one more try and I'll make it to the next region or complete the next goal."

I wouldn't want to pay full price for it
date: but I recommend it when its bundled or on sale."

reviewText: Race The Sun reminds me a lot of games like Jetpack Joyride and Cube Runner. It takes the endless runner aspects of both games and also uses the mission mechanic that makes Jetpack Joyride so addicting. I constantly found myself saying just one more run when I knew I was close to finally finishing a mission. Unlocking new things with each level that I gained kept me involved and wanting to keep ♥♥♥♥♥ing those missions done. The level creator is exceedingly thorough but with no real way to share levels yet, I eagerly await Steam Workshop, in the mean time the editor is simply a nice gesture. The visual style is simple yet pleasing and I loved visiting new worlds just to see what was in store for me. At the end of the day, if you loved Jetpack Joyride or are looking for a great game to play while waiting for friends to go play multiplayer with then this is for you and, heck, even if you don't fit those catagories you should still check the game out.

reviewText:
As alluded to in the title, the goal of Race The Sun is to travel for as long as possible, using quick reflexes to avoid obstacles and shadows while increasing your score before the sun eventually sets. Along the way you'll need to pick up scattered energy bursts to help fend off the impending darkness, at which point your solar-powered ship will begin to slow down considerably before finally stopping all together. The racing itself feels very slick and there's a terrific sense of tension that hits once you advance beyond the first couple regions and reach some truly heinous areas. The blocky and minimalistic visual style is surprisingly good-looking in motion, thanks largely to some really nice lighting effects. There isn't a whole lot of variety to the soundtrack but what's there is still quite solid. New tracks are procedurally-generated every 24 hours, and the use of leaderboards help make high-score chasing a reason to keep coming back.

The control scheme is very simplistic (analog stick to move, action button to jump when available) but I couldn't help but notice a slight yet noticeable amount of lag while playing that is directly tied to v-sync. There's no in-game option to turn it off, but I was able to force it off using RadeonPro for my AMD card. Being limited to a single track each day can also make runs a bit repetitive, a feeling that's enhanced by the limited soundtrack and oft-repeated backgrounds. Thankfully there is Steam Workshop integration so that players can create their own tracks for others to enjoy.

(EDIT: In regards to runs becoming repetitive - After playing a bit more, I now feel like it isn't as big a concern as I initially thought. Each track/region is loaded with branching paths in addition to portals that temporarily take you to bizarre alternate regions. This helps make each run feel a little more unique if you to decide to mix it up and take different routes each time.)

Despite a couple small issues, Race The Sun is a beautiful and simple yet thrilling endless runner. Runs may only last for a few minutes at a time, but it makes for some exciting bursts of racing that will test your concentration and timing.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Man, what an engaging game. It doesn't do much, but it's great at what it does. If you like adrenaline-fueled arcade racing then this might be the game for you. But when I say racing, you aren't really racing oponents - as the name says you are racing the sun. You weave through obstacles at high speed in a solar-powered ship with only limited batteries, and the sun is sinking ever closer to the horizon. How far can you make it before the sun sets?

I really enjoy the way the maps work. Each day at a set time the world gets reset; a new set of procedurally generated stages are laid out and are used by everybody for the next 24 hours, with daily leaderboards as well as tracking of all-time high scores.

Surpisingly it isn't terrible to play on a keyboard, but a controller is STRONGLY recommended.

reviewText: First off, think of Race The Sun as a mobile game, but magnified onto a larger screen. There is no story, no dialogue: just the simple objective of don't die. That includes getting as far as you can while the sun is still up, as you are a solar powered aircraft (hence the title, Race the Sun). So pretty much it's a time trial, except instead of numbers on a timer, it's a natural time limit. Controls are intuitive and simple, like many other platformers. As you progress in the game you'll get more abilites and things to collect while dodging huge rotating boxes and manoeuvring through narrow tunnels. There is also a level designer, although that was too complex for me to figure out how to use, and I decided just racing would be a better use of my time.\nOverall, this is a fun, action packed platformer with beautiful minimalist graphics that brings a new dynamic of racing the Sun until it sets. Highly recommended, but not for its price. I bought it for $2 while it was on sale, and for that it is more than worth it. However, $10 might be a little on the pricey side for a game with its amount of content.\nRegardless of the price, I rate it 8/10 for what it is.

reviewText: This is a very respectable little diversion, especially for the wonderful price of free. It's sort of a procedurally generated Wipeout where you just fly forwards as fast as you can, picking up power-ups and trying to get to the end of the level without crashing into stuff. It's very stylized, and the sunset conceit gives it a memorable look. Much like Wipeout, the mechanics are essentially based on a trial-and-error process of learning the optimal paths through the level, but by recreating those levels every 24 hours it theoretically remains interesting. Honestly, i played it for a day and then never went back because i don't find the repetitive-death mechanic very compelling, but for an hour or two it was entertaining and pretty.

reviewText: Race the Sun is a minimalist endless runner where you fly a solar powered ship towards the sun until you crash or the sun sets. You have challenges and level up in much the same way as other popular endless runners (e.g. Jetpack Joyride), but there are no microtransactions or ads in this PC game. It's a lot of fun, and addictive, kind of reminiscent of the original Star Fox in visuals. The game lacks polish in several noticeable areas (one of them being that my score usually doesn't get added to the leaderboard).

Simple yet elegant and fun game, your goal is to race towards the sun while avoiding obstacles.
When you start playing the game you will realize you can only move left and right but you probably won't even finish the first stage on your few first tries since it's more complex than that, there's various obstacles that if you crash head-on will be instant death, and they get harder the further you go/the more the sun has set.
Well, you probably would be done if that is all this game had to it, but hey, how about upgrades?
You can level up by completing challenges set by the game which ranges from simple score few points" to "complete a set number of  stages just turning left/right in a single run" which then will provide you with level-ups that will soon enable you to do such thing as jumps
date: adding a new dimension to game
hoursPlayed: a whole new difficulty (Apocalypse) for you tryhards
voteText: decals to customize your ships and few other things.\nMusic is pretty nice too

votesHelpful: and the feeling of acomplishment of getting further each run is really satisfying

then you ask: "So it's just another unlock upgrades or you aren't getting very far game?"
to which I answer : "No."
You probably can get very far without any upgrades if you know what obstacles are ahead and with a bit of planning.
Another upside is that the stages changes everyday and you can create/play custom stages made by other players so there's replay value to be had.
I would give it a 8/10

reviewText:
In Race The Sun, you fly a solar powered hovercraft through an obstacle course, while the sun descends the sky. Your goal is to stay alive as long as possible to earn a high score. The course is divided into regions, which start off fairly relaxed as you fly through wide open spaces and around static objects, but gets progressively more intense as you squeeze through narrow gaps and make split second reactions to avoid moving objects. The race ends either when you crash, or run out of sunlight.

Along the way you can collect various pickups. Blues increase your score, greens let you jump over obstacles, yellows give a speed boost and increase remaining sun time and purples allow you to respawn one time after a crash.

During a race you can also work towards completing challenges such as collecting x number of pickups or earning a specific score. Every few challenges completed will grant you a level up and unlock a new pickup, or an item to equip on your craft. These items grant useful abilities, for example, the magnet will attract nearby pickups, and the jump storage lets you carry two jump pickups instead of one. But you have limited item slots, so your choice can influence your playing style.

The map is procedurally generated every 24 hours, which means success depends more on skill than memorising the map. It also helps to keep the game fresh. Graphics are minimal, but that's actually a good thing. When you're flying at such high speeds, more detail would be distracting. Controls work well with either keyboard or 360 pad. I haven't noticed any bugs or crashes.

Race The Sun is a simple concept with excellent execution, and it can be really fun when played in short sessions. I currently have logged 78 hours on Audiosurf and 29 hours on Aaaaa playing half an hour at a time, and I can see myself doing similar with Race The Sun.

I definitely recommend checking this game out, and with such a low purchase price, there's no need to wait for a sale.

reviewText:
Type of Game:

3D Endless Runner

Version Played:

PC version through Steam

Similar Games:

Temple Run, Bit.Trip Runner, and to a lesser degree Star Fox (in the graphics department)

The Good:

An immediately satisfying arcade experience that is very easy to pick-up and play at any time
Procedurally generated levels that are never the same layout each day
There are also “themed” worlds which mix up the environment when progressing in the game
Wide open racing area that gives the player the freedom to move wherever they would want, avoiding obstacles as they do so of course
Hypnotically relaxing soundtrack and sound effects that support the overall aesthetic of the game
Playing with a controller and headphones is quite a trance-like and serene experience
Progression is natural and during the earlier stages it helps introduce game mechanics that then eventually turn into cosmetic and power-up unlockables
While the game is relaxing in a Rez sort of way, it also presents quite a challenge in being able to “twitch” the ship out of the way of oncoming objects
Leader-boards are a welcome addition that will appeal to those high score achievers among us
The developers (Flippfly) do an excellent job updating the game and staying active within the Race The Sun community, which is always good to see for indie games
There is also a level editor, which adds to the replay-ability of the title

The Bad:

The explosion animations and physics are rudimentary and considering how often the player sees them it feels like they could have been more robust and interesting
Seeing the ship break into pieces and spread across the level would have appealed to the spectacle driven gamers
Replay-ability will be an issue in the long run for Race The Sun, as is common with most arcade “pick up and play” style games
The level editor definitely helps in this department

Can you play it while the children are awake?:

You sure can. The graphics are very Starfox-esque and the content is mild. The could even be a game that they would enjoy playing with you, though there is no multiplayer outside of the leader-boards.

Did I make time to complete it?:

An endless runner really doesn’t end and that is the point. I enjoyed playing it for short bursts and imagine I will continue to do so during the times when I’m taking a break from a larger experience.

Recommended Purchase Price:

The game is a blast and can be enjoyed by anyone. Flying your ship down a vast and infinite world is exciting and fun. The fact that the worlds change every day is a huge bonus and the progression system keeps you coming back to play “one more round”. Though the game may lose your interest down the road, the content and design are well worth the asking price. The developers will be a team to watch going forward, as well:

$9.99

or

100% of current retail value of $9.99

http://www.gamersglance.com

reviewText:
A fairly simple game with simplistic, minimal graphics and a solid concept, Race The Sun will satisfy your need for arcade style dodging games.

It doesn't do much more, but then it also doesn't ask for more, or need to do more. You can go for achievements, level up to get new bonusses for your ship, and just try to beat your(Or your friends' records.

The only con I can at this point think of is that it is somewhat repetitive(The levels are remade daily though, so you can always come back tomorrow), and that it is rather slow in letting you unlock things.

All in all, a solid game and worth a playthrough or two, but don't count on spending several days locked into this game. It's not that kind of game

reviewText:
It's simple. Fun and quite addicting. The title pratically states what this game is going to be about. Not only that but with workshop compability. Unique and challenging maps are created for gamers to race on. (Note this isn't a racing game with other players or bots if you got that impression).

You should honestly have no trouble playing this game. It's not stressful, or has this horror game element. It's just one of those kick back and relax games. The only thing i will suggest is rebinding the movement keys from the direction keys to the W,A,S,D keys. But honestly by the fifth or tenth run on the same map (that is ever changing, thanks to the active development team). You won't have to rebind the keys to remember what is in front of you.

If you want simple and enjoyable games. Then i recommend this one.

reviewText:
This game is a four letter word, namely ♥♥♥♥!

or maybe a divine word and a four letter word, such as HOLY ♥♥♥♥!

In otherwords.....  this game is simply amazing.  It also might give you a heart attack, or make you feel all giggity on the inside, butterflies in the stomach and such.  That's the effect I'm getting right now; something between that and the heart-pounding fight or flight adrenaline rush of a century (a lil hyperbole there).

You fly in the smoothest riding, touchiest to control aircraft in the universe cruising at lightning speed.  Every crash brings both a sense of dread and elation!  After awhile, crashing becomes insanely fun, actually!  In this game, unlike sex, lasting 3 minutes is a good thing!  What feels even more good than the ejaculatory experience of exploding into objects with your 'aircraft' is the experience of weaving impossibly through obstacles, or richocheting off of them to extreme heights only to be thrown down into a chaotically destructive maze of impossibility.  BUY THIS ♥♥♥♥.  It's also similar to Super Hexagon and I thought it would be useful to compare the two, since I am so in love with that game as well, so.....

THE BREAKDOWN:  (Comparison of Race the Sun and Super Hexagon)

On the annoying scale: I would rank it slightly under SuperHexagon which is a game that should also be in your library if you end up being into this game, or if you haven't already bought it.... SH, as it stands is the most annoying/frustrating game of all time.  RtS: 8 , SH: 10

Challenge/Difficulty:  I would have to say about the same thing here, but it's a close match.  RtS: 9, SH: 10

Fun Factor:  BOTH 10's!

Visual Appeal:  This is where Race the Sun takes the lead, with a score that is relative to this type of very minimalist arcade game:  RtS: 10, SH: 8

Music Annoyingness: 10 - 10

Mind-♥♥♥♥ing Awesomeness:  10-10

reviewText: If you are looking for a slow and complex runner game, it is not here. This game can be very difficult very quickly, but it does everything with polish. Simple, clean, and fast. The trailer really shows the ideas and speed of the game, if you think it's too fast or repetitive then you won't like the game. But I've found it very enjoyable. A slower-speed option could help newer players through the awkward progression system, but the game is still solid.\n\nI've never really been a fan of the runner genre, but this game cleans up the issues and polished the best parts. Still, the amount of content is fair, but I don't think the game is incredibly replayable. Most reviewers are around 5 hours or less, with very few above 10. I consider myself nearly done" with the game

reviewText: Race the Sun is a Endless Runner type Indie game.\nIt is Fast paced and gets Faster as the game goes on the goal is to Race The Sun and not Die, you can do this by picking up yellow Boosters" to reverse the setting of the sun for a small moment

hoursPlayed: but you increase your multiplier by picking up "Tris" every 5 Tris ups your multplier by 1x.\nYou also have mini objective to complete and in doing so you get either 1/2/3 Points after a set about of points you unlock stuff like powerups to equip on your ship there is stuff like "Magnet" to increase your pickup range of tris and powerups

and there is also decals you can put on your wins (you unlock the left wing decals first then later the Right wing decals).

My over all rating for this game is 8.5/10

reviewText:
Race The Sun is a simple game that I enjoyed a lot. The game itself is hard to describe, at its most basic I would say it comes down to a race against time/ dodging obstacles. Besides the fast paced gameplay, where Race the Sun excels is its ambiance and environment. they are simplistic but memorable providing a relaxing atmosphere even amongst the fast speed and reflex testing gameplay.

To top it off not only are there multiple modes in Race the Sun, the game comes with a detailed level/world editor for custom content. This is always a plus when user generated content can be made, extending the lifespan of a game considerably.

Overall I would recommend this game to fans of indie games, racing games, or even rhythm games like super hexagon.

reviewText:
So I finally stopped dreaming about flying a million miles an hour... SO I figure it's time to give my two cents.

Race the Sun is a simplistic speed game with the objective of not crashing and staying alive in front of the suns rays and not always in the shadows. (You are a solar craft after all.) The game is really calming or super intense with the music supplemented for the regions. The artwork is so clean and minimalistic, you don't get distracted by specfic textures or colors. The specfic terrain changes: change with ship level, day to day, and also how far into the regions you take your craft.

If you're good you can fly through the map banking and barrel rolling the entire time left or right, or slalom style. The game feels to have specific lanes that if you were to be inbetween two lanes, you would feel safe but not challenged by the obstacles. Eventually, this would be met with a dead end of terrain somewhere along the lines if you were to continue really any path just straight forward. It's designed to make you keep looking for openings and to take risks to find the powerups you need and sometimes there are several ways to approach the old (and new) areas you needed more help with. There's Jumps, Emergency lives that spit you out at high altitudes, turning jets eventually to make you more like Starfox. The boosts are probably your bread and butter if you cn figure out the maps because getting high scores on this game requires as much distance as it does the Tris that add to your score.

This game is very addicting, will keep you playing to explore and try to pull off insane moves to get where you want to be.

reviewText:
The balls... Ohgodwhy.

Race the sun is incredibly simplistic but do not let that fool you. This amazing little thing has a nack to make you want to keep trying, it draws you in because you enjoy playing it while also wanting to stab it for both being patronising and incredibly difficult at times.

Minimalistic controls feel tight and really well balanced to the feel of the game and just in general. This is beyond a good thing because the maps have so much substance, changing it up with each new region you fly through.

Graphics are quite attractive and with steam workshop being enabled, people's wonderful imaginations run wild and make maps even prettier, also deadlier. Your aircraft I feel as though was modelled off a sparrow, well... You most certainly feel like one by the end of the game and even get a shiny achievement for such!

The fast pace of this game makes this a must play for casual, hardcore and all gamers alike.

reviewText:
Race the Sun isn't bad, but it's not really getting me hot and bothered for endless runner action, either.

I mean, I'm all for Kickstarted games that are seemingly like a '♥♥♥♥ you' to the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ gamer crowd, and Race the Sun's premise is just that: An endless runner game that feels like it should play on a phone, but has been released for the PC. (It did get ported to mobile devices later on, though.)

The game is mostly solid, looks beautiful and clean, and controls pretty well. With the exception of the one user world I tried. I like how you can traverse to actual 'worlds' that other players have created while you're running through the game, but the one I tried was white on black and all the ground obstacles were white and hidden by the landscape, and I was irritated when I hit a white car while driving over a white foreground and died, because I couldn't ♥♥♥♥ing see what killed me! I pin the blame on the designer on that level, though.

The game advertises a really neat co-op 'clan' premise where your friends can pick up after you've died in your game, but since I'm a Forever Alone and I think co-op is more gimmick than feature at this point, I didn't get the chance to try that out.

There's not much going on in solo-play, other than 'endless running' and 'obligatory RPG mechanics' and 'RPG challenges with no choice to skip over the boring ones'. However, if you're here to chase scores and chew bubblegum, that gum is going to fall out of your mouth while you figure out the best path to get all the points so you can try in vain to beat the guy who hacked himself into the #1 spot on the leaderboards. Much like you're trying to beat the sun, you'll never beat the #1 guy on the leaderboards, because leaderboards in video games in 2015 are invitations for hackers to 'beat the system' and 'vote for Ron Paul'.

So I don't feel much love or hate for Race the Sun. If you're looking for an endless runner, though, you could get this one?

reviewText:
Easy to learn, hard to master... just how a game should be.

The courses change every day, giving you a new and interesting problem to solve every day.  I take a small dose of this game with breakfast.  Its controls are simple... so much so that it can played with one hand, leaving your other to shove your breakfast burrito into your face.  But don't let that fool you.  RTS is a game that demands your attention and reflexes, but with great reward.

Not very graphically intense, but it's better this way.  Your objective is simple, your controls are simple, and your environment should match, especially given that this is a a fast reflex and short-term planning game.  Complexity would only create more problems in the way of hitbox management and identification.  Immersion, as a result, is minimal yet engaging.

Progression can be a bit slow through the ship levels, but if you focus, you can achieve even some of the goals that seem more difficult than the others, resulting in a bigger jump through the leveling process.

And then... the unlocked mode.  I won't spoil it, but... Yeah.  Awesome.

+1.  Time is running out.

reviewText:
TL;DR: I recommend this game but only on sale, there's just not enough here to be worth $9.99 plus $1.99 for DLC that really should've been part of the base game.

[Difficulty - average]: It can be easy or hard depending on your ship configuration, memorizing abilty and reflexes.

[Controls - good]: You have turn left, turn right, and use special ability... pretty simple to understand.

[Music - good]: It's not too distracting but manages to create an atmosphere that fits with racing a setting sun. Or you can just turn it off and use your own music of choice which is always a plus for games.

[Graphics - good]: It's simple and smooth which is a plus when reflexes are important to playing at high speeds and any framerate drop or stuttering could spell death. I hate graphic dependant games since they're too much for my older computer, luckily there's no issue at all with this game so just about anyone can play it.

[Content - average]: As I said at the top, there isn't much to do in this game and that's mainly because it's all hidden behind unlock requirements which can take awhile to actually unlock. You can only have one ship attachment at the beginning and I have no idea how long it takes to actually get to the point where you can have multiple ones equipped. I'm still at the point where I have 2 choices for levels, the base mode that has a set level that changes every 24 hours or Apocalypse mode which is the base mode with more explosions. Credits mode doesn't count because you can literally afk while doing it because all you do is fly straight and wait for it to end. (Why they didn't have you interact with them by having you dodge falling credits seems like a huge waste). It does have a map editor which adds some feeling of community to it but again you have no choices for level selection beyond what is randomly generated each day.
Then you have the Sunrise DLC which is a freestyle zen mode from what I understand of the description. (Why on earth that wasn't included in the basic game which was already lacking in stuff to do is also beyond me).

[Overall - good]: Despite the complaints I have for the content, this game is a good time-killer. The built-in games a computer OS comes with (think Solitaire, Minesweeper, or Pinball) are probably the most played games just because you don't always have the time or motivation to commit to a whole game that could take hours to complete.  This game fits into that category of games very well. However it is simply not worth the $12 price tag for it and the Sunrise DLC, between $5 and $8 is closer to what this game should be at.

reviewText:
Race the Sun is a racing game where a solar aircraft tries to catch up the sun while dodging obsticles and looking for boosters.

These are the Pros and Cons :

Pros :
-EXTREMELY good effects (especially the sun ray and shadows)
-EXTREMELY hard but enjoyable gaming
-EXTERMELY smooth controls
-Enjoyable music
-Few but useful attachments
-Awsome looking explosion

Cons :
-It may be too difficult for beginners
-The developer mistaken aileron roll as barrel roll (It's aileron roll in the game)

Suggestions :
-Easier map for beginners
-More spacecraft designs

Overall :
EXTREMELY hard gameplay, but the effects, music and the graphics makes me can't stop playing it.
9/10

reviewText:
Easy to learn, hard to master... just how a game should be.

The courses change every day, giving you a new and interesting problem to solve every day.  I take a small dose of this game with breakfast.  Its controls are simple... so much so that it can played with one hand, leaving your other to shove your breakfast burrito into your face.  But don't let that fool you.  RTS is a game that demands your attention and reflexes, but with great reward.

Not very graphically intense, but it's better this way.  Your objective is simple, your controls are simple, and your environment should match, especially given that this is a a fast reflex and short-term planning game.  Complexity would only create more problems in the way of hitbox management and identification.  Immersion, as a result, is minimal yet engaging.

Progression can be a bit slow through the ship levels, but if you focus, you can achieve even some of the goals that seem more difficult than the others, resulting in a bigger jump through the leveling process.

And then... the unlocked mode.  I won't spoil it, but... Yeah.  Awesome.

+1.  Time is running out.

reviewText:
Race the Sun isn't bad, but it's not really getting me hot and bothered for endless runner action, either.

I mean, I'm all for Kickstarted games that are seemingly like a '♥♥♥♥ you' to the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ gamer crowd, and Race the Sun's premise is just that: An endless runner game that feels like it should play on a phone, but has been released for the PC. (It did get ported to mobile devices later on, though.)

The game is mostly solid, looks beautiful and clean, and controls pretty well. With the exception of the one user world I tried. I like how you can traverse to actual 'worlds' that other players have created while you're running through the game, but the one I tried was white on black and all the ground obstacles were white and hidden by the landscape, and I was irritated when I hit a white car while driving over a white foreground and died, because I couldn't ♥♥♥♥ing see what killed me! I pin the blame on the designer on that level, though.

The game advertises a really neat co-op 'clan' premise where your friends can pick up after you've died in your game, but since I'm a Forever Alone and I think co-op is more gimmick than feature at this point, I didn't get the chance to try that out.

There's not much going on in solo-play, other than 'endless running' and 'obligatory RPG mechanics' and 'RPG challenges with no choice to skip over the boring ones'. However, if you're here to chase scores and chew bubblegum, that gum is going to fall out of your mouth while you figure out the best path to get all the points so you can try in vain to beat the guy who hacked himself into the #1 spot on the leaderboards. Much like you're trying to beat the sun, you'll never beat the #1 guy on the leaderboards, because leaderboards in video games in 2015 are invitations for hackers to 'beat the system' and 'vote for Ron Paul'.

So I don't feel much love or hate for Race the Sun. If you're looking for an endless runner, though, you could get this one?

reviewText:
The balls... Ohgodwhy.

Race the sun is incredibly simplistic but do not let that fool you. This amazing little thing has a nack to make you want to keep trying, it draws you in because you enjoy playing it while also wanting to stab it for both being patronising and incredibly difficult at times.

Minimalistic controls feel tight and really well balanced to the feel of the game and just in general. This is beyond a good thing because the maps have so much substance, changing it up with each new region you fly through.

Graphics are quite attractive and with steam workshop being enabled, people's wonderful imaginations run wild and make maps even prettier, also deadlier. Your aircraft I feel as though was modelled off a sparrow, well... You most certainly feel like one by the end of the game and even get a shiny achievement for such!

The fast pace of this game makes this a must play for casual, hardcore and all gamers alike.

reviewText: I thought i would never reach second level, at most 10th. But now i'm on 20th and i'm confident i can reach more. This is a simple game to play with your nerves. Flying on a high velocity trying to avoid obstacles. At first it seems you can't make it. But it has nice difficulty curve. There are always 3 objectives to complete and you can complete them ALL, just might need some time to upgrade for some of them. And you get better at controlling the plane as time goes (playing with keyboard though, gamepad lags a bit). Another big plus, that every day it looks differently (don't know if they do it manually or levels generate procedururally). They have similarities and are composed of same objects, but still have some unique spots, so you want to check it out next day. And there are users generated levels also.

reviewText:
Title gives away the idea of this game. You pilot a solar powered craft trying to catch the setting sun. You can only try to but you cannot win as the sun will eventually set and you will run out of power.

You race in a world that is randomly generated daily so the game offers a lot of replayability. While you can only move towards the sun the map is basically endless in every direction giving you a lot of room to manouver. Completing specific tasks in the game earns powerups that can make you last longer like shield against collisions, jump to avoid obstacles and ability to warp levels. At times the gameplay can be hectic and fast but still i’d say that Race the Sun is most of all a meditative experience. It’s a game that you might play for 10 minutes at a time or so but not much longer.

No matter how hard you try the sun will eventually set. It is the journey that holds value.

reviewText:
First of all, I’ll start of by saying that I’m extremely grateful towards the developers, Aaron & Forest, for granting me early access to their game, Race the Sun. Upon booting up the game I was greeted with a simple options screen, which I was pretty impressed about, as this game is only in its early stages, yet the developers still took the time to add some configuration choices, e.g. resolution, graphics quality, controls, etc…

Now, I’m in the game, & immediately some extremely intense music starts rolling, I’m feeling pumped and then my solar plane just shoots out of nowhere, the controls are displayed, (Left & Right keys to steer), and I’m straight into the action!, dodging pyramids, trees, spheres and various other low-polygon 3D shapes. If I were to sum this game up in a sentence, it would go something like this, “Fast-paced, Side-scrolling, action, thriller”. I was having an absolute blast! I often found myself on the edge of my chair, biting my teeth, and swearing just as clipped a tiny tree.

All in all, the game’s pace is incredible, not to fast, not to slow. The ascending music at the beginning of each round really sets the intense mood. The graphics aren’t exactly crisp, but it wasn’t really something I took too much notice of while my solar plane was speeding around. Something that the developers need to work on in my opinion, is the Sun, as the games is based around it, I thought it would get more attention, but after you unlock the ability to send the sun back up, you never really take notice of it.

That’s all for this review, I hope you enjoyed this quick (or rather long) insight on Race The Sun.
Regards, Paul
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've clocked up countless hours on this before it came to Steam and although it only does one thing, it does it VERY well. Ever had one of those conversations with your mother and weren't really paying attention, you can be playing this game with just one hand those hours of listening to how next door's neighbour's cat has ripped up another plant. Ever had to burp a baby for what seems forever, well, one hand for the burp, the other for this. Simple, well-honed controls that are tight and responsive, fully rebindable, clear aesthetic design and that sense of speed at 90fps (+) just has to be seen to be believed...

It's beautiful, simple and elegant. It doesn't pretend to do anything more than one thing - to get as far as you can before the sun sets. And, with a number of well-planned unlocks and boosts available as you sink more time in, it keeps on giving you another reason to play more.

Can't recommend it enough for what it does. And I'm just hoping it gets the praise it deserves!

I often found myself raging internally whilst playing Race the Sun. I'd get so far, just to crash right into a block that wasn't there a second ago. This only fueled my desire to try again, and again, and again, making this game fairly addictive.

Race the Sun's objective is to simply Race the Sun"

Race the Sun progressively built up my frustration when I played it for long periods of time. The gameplay works best when experienced in small bursts. reviewText:
Race the Sun reminds me in many ways of the Java-based title flood runner -- another endless runner that would see you piloting a hovercraft of sorts through procedurally generated terrain, populated by increasingly dense simple shapes. flood runner was a game that proved so instantly accessible and absurdly addictive that our school at the time had to ban every site that carried it, just to make sure we did some work.

Race the Sun also falls into that mould. Ostensibly an endless runner with two simple rules -- always move forward, and never crash -- players are free to roam about the minimalist landscapes in lateral fashion via a solar-powered vehicle. Indeed, you'll need to in order to avoid the rush of oncoming shapes and structures. The turning circle of your ship is sluggish to begin with, and decisive flying is of paramount importance.

The game begins with languid sojourns through open, spacious environments, the sun atop the horizon constantly threatening to set and bring your journey to an end. There are pickups strewn liberally across the maps: blue ones (Tris) add to your score multiplier, green ones earn you the ability to make a single jump, the white ones enshrined in soft pillars of light prolong the day and speed up your craft, and then there's the rare pink object which gives you one free pass when it comes to the crunch.

Diverting from the easy, straight course to risk ruin amidst the denser pockets of each level in order to chase down pickups seems needless at the very start But the first time the sun sets and leaves your craft without power, stranded ignobly and with a lamentable score, you begin to realise the importance of chasing them down.

There's some progression in there too, with Jetpack Joyride-esque objectives in 1-star, 2-star, and 3-star difficulty flavourings, the completion of which will help to boost your pilot ranking. Some of these missions see you accumulating Tris or travelling a certain distance, others might have you performing a certain number of barrel rolls (thereby forcing you to move laterally a lot more than you would) within the space of a single run, or only turning left. There's a pleasant sense of accomplishment that follow the completion of some of these things

One of the best things about the whole experience is the relay system. If you're finding the game too tricky, you can make use of the little option at the end of each run that allows you to share a relay point via email or across social networks like Twitter and Facebook. Basically, another player can then start from where you finished, and then when they crash or run out of solar power, the chain can be continued. Buddy up with a friend, and you can leapfrog one another to maximise points and distance, helping to unlock more of the fiendish 3-star accomplishments. You can only create a four-stage relay, but it works very nicely indeed.

So race the sun great game if you have a pc you need this even on the lowest graphical settings this game is a thrill to play

Another well deserved 10/10

reviewText:
Tot's Rundown: Don't buy this game expecting to play it for hours in one sitting, or a lot of depth. Buy it for an easy-going experience that will keep you coming back day after day.

Race The Sun is a simple game at heart, and as such I just don't think it's realistic to expect to get hours of gameplay out of it in one sitting. I don't think that's what the game sets out to do, either. What it does do wonderfully is provide a great pick-up-and-play title that can easily become a daily routine.

Watch the trailer or some other videos of it, and you'll get the basic premise. Yep, you just dodge stuff. There is no throttle and there is no brake, you're simply flying as fast and as far as you can before the sun - your source of energy - sets on the horizon. There are various pickups which make the gameplay more varied as you progress, such as an essential item that makes the sun rise in the sky for that much needed extended time. It's almost reminiscent of an old arcade-style racer, where when you ran out of time you had to insert more quarters, only without the quarters.

The key aspect of this game is the changing worlds. Every day they release a new world for you to race in, so the challenge won't be the same as the last time you played it. And each world, at that, can be pleasantly varied as you fly farther and farther, progressing through the world's stages." Add in custom user-made worlds (the game comes with a world editor) and Steam Workshop integration incoming
date: and you've got a whole lot of replayability."

reviewText:
I see some people are having a tough time choosing if to buy this game or not so i will go over the pros and the cons.

Pros
-fastpaced
-both casual players and hardcore players can play
-world resets
-the addition of the workshop

Cons
-can get repetitive
-leveling is difficult when higher than about 10
-a lot of repetition
-tedious for some of the challenges

So with these pros and cons that I thought of, You can decide for yourself or if you want my opionion on this game it is, this game will make you want to punch you computer screen once you play for long periods of time, you will not only see a ton of repetition if you go down the same path (remember you can go either way), and last i would only tell you to buy this if you dont get mad easily. So I say yes to most but to some I would have to say no, but you can never tell what side you are on till you try the game

-First- Find out what time the world resets for you (i.e. My world resets at 10pm) once you have found out the time minus 2 hours and add 2 hours from that number. (i.e. My case it would be 8pm and 12am)

-Second- Play the game only during these time zones. (One note since the world resets during this time don't try for challenges it might get difficult)

This is how i can play this game for a long period of time without wanting to punch my computer screen. I do recommend this tip for anyone who doesn't like to play the game for more than 2 hours because of repetition.

Don't be fooled by it starting simple - the game builds on itself over and over, rewarding you for playing with new mechanics and customization.

Since I got a good amount of value out of it, I would still recommend this game.
