reviewText:
Race the Sun offers immersive, adrenaline packed experience; yet it's still the kind of game you can jump right into when you just have a few minutes to kill. Now that I think about it, I feel like that is a really rare combo to find in a game, at least for me it is...

What is it about? / Gameplay
It's a pretty basic endless runner with an interesting twist. You are controlling an aircraft through obstacle-littered world at high velocity. Being solar-powered, shadows and sunset are your main concern. You must keep going fast enough to delay the inevitable end of your futile race for as long as possible…

The gameplay is very simplistic. Fly, dodge, jump, and collect stuff along the way. That's all I've been doing, because that's all there is to do in this game. Yet, strangely enough, I still find myself craving for more of the same…
The world you're flying through is divided into a regions, each being more difficult, due to rising ammount and variety of obstacles. The whole map is re-generated daily, offering a slightly different experience every day. I say slightly, because some elements always start to appear in the same regions, which I feel is fair. Anyway, the ever changing world keeps the game fresh, and if that's not enough for you, there are another two (unlockable) game modes and a level editor with Steam Workshop support.
The game sets various different challenges -  something like collect XY points in one run" for example. Completing these challenges unlocks new ship upgrades
date:
pick-ups and bunch of other stuff. There are also leaderboards and achievements to make your effort less pointless.

reviewText:
Race the Sun is, as it says on steam, a fast-paced racing game, and while it is singleplayer, there is a daily leaderboard that does as leaderboards do. In Race the Sun, you race through courses that vary every day. While the courses are not identical to the previous day's course, they will contain similar parts for each round, the varying being where the parts are pieced together.

I have found this game to be rather addictive at times, partially due to the achievements and leaderboard. It is easy to restart a round, and playing on a course set for a specific day multiple times allows you to learn how the course for the day runs and how to improve on your previous score.

The graphics are simple but beautiful, and while I do like the ingame music sometimes, I typically do runs with the ingame music turned off and my own music playing in the background. The game controls well and often relies on how precise you can be with your car movement. While the game is challenging, I have found it to be rather relaxing, doing some runs for personal bests and a high(ish) spot on the leaderboard, and other runs to relax and just see how far I can get, regardless of my score.

So if you are looking for a good challenge or just a fun racing game, get Race the Sun.

reviewText:
A non-biased Quick Look @ the game:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rAAI-Zvt1s0

You are a solar craft. The sun is your death timer. Hurtle towards the sunset at breakneck speed in a futile race against time. Delay the inevitable by catching energy boosts which reverse the setting sun - if only for a moment.

Race The Sun is inspired by arcade games of the past with a focus on highscores, short game sessions, and a sense of pure fun mingled with a nerve-wracking tension. The rules are simple: don't crash, stay in the light, and don't slow down! -  Recommended!

reviewText:
I don't normally care for runner games unless they do something to keep me invested. A lot of them now have levels to earn and missions to do and unlocks to... unlock, and Race the Sun is no different. But even after unlocking everything, I still go back to it now and then because of how solid the basic gameplay is.

You're the pilot of a solar-powered hovercraft, speeding towards the setting sun in an attempt to stay in daylight. Shadows cast by mountains, structures, and clouds will all slow you down, and when the sun sets, you're done. To keep up with the sun you'll need to dodge the many obstacles in your wide-open path, as well as pick up booster items to thrust you forward at even higher speed. I wasn't kidding about speeding towards the sun, because even your regular pace feels like hundreds of miles per hour. Dodging obstacles and steering into pickups is thrilling and harrowing, and pulling off tight maneuvers is always satisfying.

There are all manner of items to pick up across the levels like point multipliers, jumps, shields, and more. Completing tasks like clearing 3 levels without bumping anything or jumping 5 times earns you XP towards new ranks, which unlock upgrades and decals for your ship. There are 25 ranks to earn, giving you a goal for at least a few hours. Even beyond that there are reasons to keep flying, though. The main levels change every day, giving you new layouts to tackle. There's also a hard mode and a maze mode to unlock, and user-created levels to try, including one user-created level hidden in the regular game each day!

The presentation is a unique blend of stark, clean visuals, soothing soundtrack, and a strangely casual tone to the text. All the elements are there for a game that you can load up for 5 or 10 minutes for a quick run, or turn on for an hour and work at, or start the free-flight mode and just chill. There's no fighting so it won't properly scratch that Starfox itch you might get from the screenshots, but it's well worth a few hours of your time to explore and enjoy.

reviewText:
Post-Rock: The Video Game.

It's essentially a rogue-like racing game. If that idea appeals to you, I can't reccomend this game enough.

It's fun, it's addictive, it's challenging, it's beautiful. There's nothing else like it. The fact that the worlds are randomly generated makes it something even greater that I will probably keep playing for a very long time.

reviewText:
This review will be split into two parts, the game and the level editor.

Game: Even though simplistic, that is the charm to this game.  It is quite fun to play and the constant changing of worlds makes for a nice touch. Lighting is great and controller support is fluent.

Level Editor:  No! Just No!  It is way to buggy.  I made a world for a contest of theirs and had to redo my level 3 times due to one major bug of it.  The final time, I put so many hours of work into making my objects for this and when I went to make patterns, the pattern editor broke.  I tried everything short of backing up and reinstalling the game, but without files for it, I cannot back it up. I deleted the world and the game itself due to this, since I cannot even look at the game anymore.  I will recommend the game for playing, but if you want to use the editor, give it a year longer.  They shouldn't have made a contest on such a buggy editor, even though they warned us it is buggy, that just tells me that they are not professional with editors.

reviewText: A fast-paced game with a simple but elegant aesthetic to it, Race The Sun is one thing and does it very, very well. This game feels like a game similar to the likes of F-Zero, Wipeout, and Extreme-G only there are no other racers, just you and the setting sun. Which you can't ever catch. As soon as the game is started you're doomed to either collide with something or watch the sun set despite your best efforts, but it's very compelling to try again and see if you can get further. I highly recommend this game if you're even slightly interested, it's very easy to pick up and play. Combined with worlds that regenerate every day, a hard-mode world that lives up to the name Apocolypse, leaderboards, and player-built worlds, Race The Sun is a remarkable game that's perfect for those that want to go fast with a real sense of speed!

reviewText: A nice decent game. I got it for free, (which was great) and I'm pretty satisfied. It's a nice relaxing game game, with no clear objective or storyline. The plot is that you are a solar-powered craft flying and the sun, which powers your craft, is setting. You can collect energy boosts that, for a split second, stop the sun from setting. The endless concept is not something new (at all), but this game is. Good graphics and ambience, and it kind of reminds me of an iPad game I have called Forever Drive (https://itunes.apple.com/en/app/forever-drive/id442923846?mt=8) which had futuristic graphics with an endless concept AND a map editor- a perfect replica, only race-themed.\n\nSo, conclusion: I'd recommend it, but not for it's full price. Get it in a bundle, or when it's on sale.

reviewText:
You are a ship racing against a setting sun. Without solar power, your ship stalls and the game ends. This is a very fun game as other reviews attest to.

I am more interested in the Lore of this game. Does RtS take place on Earth? Is this game a depiction of a future apocalypse? Is this the last sunset?  What are these strange geometries that you navigate? Are they the ruins of once great cities? Is your ship an ark carrying the last vestiges of humanity?

Why is the ship compelled to race the sun, knowing that the sun can never be beaten.

Existential. Sysiphean. Nihilistic. Protean. Mythopoetic. Lagubrious. These are all words I would (and am) use (-ing) to describe this game.

Why do we race the sun? Because we want to stay in the light.

reviewText:
Race The Sun is a good game, and you can probably tell whether you'll like it by the screenshots and videos on the Steam page, but, in case you're not sure, allow me to elaborate.

I think the goal of the game is fairly obvious, you need to race the sun with a solar-powered spacecraft. The theme is not just a gimmick though: since some obstacles in the game project shadows, you will sometimes not be able to see the sun, and that will slow you down, meaning that the sun will set faster in the horizon. Basically, every mistake you make has an immediate and tangible effect on the game.

The controls are tight and responsive, and the hitboxes seem logical and fair most of the time (if you die, it's most likely your fault and not the game's). Plus, the view distance is not infinite, but good enough for you to be able to spot obstacles and react to them in time.

The real" goal of the game is to get as high of a score as possible by collecting "tris"
date: which are basically score multipliers. For every five tris you get
recommended: your multiplier will go up by one
hoursPlayed: but if you bump sideways into something you lose one. You lose the game when you crash into an obstacle or if your craft's battery is depleted due to lack of exposure to direct sunlight.\n\nThere are some collectible items you can find as well
voteText: which can increase your speed temporarily
helpfulPercent: allow you to jump
votesHelpful: skip the level or save you if you crash into something.\nA final thing to keep in mind is that there are some mini challenges that you need to complete in order to level up

column19: but that's not where the game exhausts its content.\n\nIf you wish to keep playing
column20: there are plenty of things to keep you occupied: first off
column21: the main game's world is reset every 24 hours
column22: which means you have some time to learn the various obstacles during the day
column23: but you will get a new challenge after you're done with it.\n\nSecondly
column25: one that is a considerably more difficult version of the standard world and another one that is actually a beatable maze
column26: which I found to be a really cool alternative take on the core gameplay.\n\nAnd
column28: you can find some special portals on the levels
column29: and those portals will lead you to an "alternate universe"
column30: which is basically a user-created level. And yes

column34: when it comes to the audiovisual aspects of the game

reviewText:
Mixed feelings. I bought this game to enjoy some high-speed flying in an open world, but in farther regions of it I actually don't get that much enjoyment because of dense, hazardous, and unforgiving landscape that keeps me crashing into something. The landscape has patterns, of course, and those patterns can be more or less efficiently learned after several runs (thus allowing you to improve your performance), but even a slightest mistake imminently turns out to be fatal. The aircraft's ability to steer left and right does not really match its acceleration; sometimes I feel like I could use a bit more agility.

The gameplay itself is relatively simple; if you watched videos on the game's page in Steam store, then you've actually seen most of what it has to offer.

If you are happy to exercise your quick reaction and fast reflexes, then you will probably find this game involving and worthy of your money. If, otherwise, you are not the best in making correct decisions in milliseconds, then you might prefer to look for the fun somewhere else.

reviewText:
A Paladin’s Steam Review: Race the Sun. A Bit Slow Paced for A Fast Endless Runner.Genre: Minimalist Endless Racer
Developed & Published by: Flippfly LLC
Platform: Windows, Mac, Linux and iOS.
Business Model: Cheaper Base Game + Single Optional DLC
Copy Purchased by Myself Overall Gameplay Thoughts
As it says on the store page, Race the Sun has you driving a solar craft across a vast, endless space filled with obstacles galore. Your only timer is a constantly setting sun that you must race towards. If the sun sets or you get caught in a long shadow for too long, the craft will run out of power and the race is over. Each world is separated by regions that get progressively harder as more objects and obstacles are thrown into your path. Within certain districts are portals to optional levels to change the pace up. Workshop support allows you to try out community created worlds though I found these got a little too difficult for my taste. There’s also a leveling system where you need to complete goals (given to you in a set of three) every time you race. Some are pretty generic with completing a certain amount of score or reaching a certain district while others can be overly difficult (do a barrel roll 20 times in a single try, yeah, still can’t accomplish that task). Additionally, your solar craft can be configured with different attachments and badges. These are unlocked as you level up and seem to be quality of life changes to your craft, not real game changers.

It’s a simplistic game where all you do is steer around objects and hit as many power ups (speed boosters and jump boosters are the most common) as you can. The high speed action takes some skill and split second decision making in order to be successful. Even then, you can easily get plastered against a wall for not reacting fast enough and that can get old fast. If there was a main complaint I’d have, it's that unlocks take way too long to get. Even after a couple of hours, I still haven’t gotten a single badge and there’s still more than half of the attachments left to unlock. There’s a constant sense of frustration at not getting much reward for making even the slightest amount of progress. I often got tired of doing the first region over and over again because I crashed on a simple rock at the beginning of the second region. I feel like there could be a better way of handling it but I have yet to see an endless runner do anything about it. Race the Sun does have procedurally generated levels but the structure is largely the same and all that really changes is what objects are in each district. RtS used to have daily challenges but they seem to have been patched out.

PC Settings and Sunrise DLC
A fairly decent set of options can be found in Race the Sun. There’s a large amount of resolutions to choose from with fullscreen on/off. A quality slider that vaguely goes from fantastic to fastest. Vsync can be enabled/disabled. There’s two audio sliders for effects and music. Both a keyboard and a controller can be used and both work equally well. The keys can be rebound with optional secondaries. The Linux version seems to work quite well too. Anti-aliasing seems tied into the quality slider. I never had any performance problems or crashing. Video and audio work well together in this game too.

The Sunrise DLC is for an optional world where there's no leaderboards, setting sun or optional objectives. It's ok but I kind of feel like its superfluous with multiple Workshop levels having the same rules. It at least looks quite pretty but I don't think $2 is worth pretty.

Final Thoughts
Race the Sun has a good visual/audio design and it's one of the few endless runners I’ve run into that doesn’t try to waste your time with some nonsense business model. It's also a decently skillful runner too and has a good sense of speed, not dependent upon gimmicky controls or QTEs to slow you down. However, I find that the pacing is a little too long between unlocks. They can take far too long and too many runs to obtain and what you end up getting doesn't really change the game for the next hundred races. So, it can be a little too boring. If you’re ok with a repetitive endless run that isn’t looking to suck the money out of your wallet, Race the Sun is something to consider. Just don’t expect too much excitement and a lot of re-racing the first region.

Read this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

reviewText:
UPDATE: Since my purchase in 2013, Race the Sun have added near-PERFECT virtual reality support. You can play this game with your Oculus Rift DK1 or DK2... and yeah, it's as bloody awesome as one could imagine. Just one more reason to go ahead and get this game now! (See links at the bottom of review for VR video)

Being a big fan of SpeedX 3D and AiRace speed on the 3DS, this game looked like a direct variation of this genre which made my decision to get this title easy. The only question mark was if Tridef Ignition could output this game in proper stereoscopic 3D and sure enough, it works perfectly with it!

The more I play it and discover its rather unique features the more I think it'll eventually be worth doing a follow up review with more detail - this game is awesome and people should know about it!

reviewText:
I almost dont recomend this game. Ill tell you why.

Pros:
The gameplay is very satisfying and the map is updated every day to provide a somewhat unique expirence.

Controller support (Not a great game with keyboard)

.....errr yeah...

Cons.
For some mind boggling reason they locked a lot of the mechanics behind some arbitrary achivement like challenges. The power ups and collectables and upgrades for your ship are all locked behind this. I almost quit the game after 10 minutes until I realized this as the game was very boring.

The whole Idea behind this is you have until the sun sets to get as far as you can. The only way to gain more time is by randomly placed yellow boost power ups. I dont like this. It means your runs are more luck based than skill. I would have prefered the blue 'score' pickups to have gained you more time instead.

That being said. There is only one game mode and one map. There is no story and no tutorial. It feels the game is lacking a large amount of content. There is a mod support but I cant be bothered to sort through all the mods to find some more maps to play. If the devs dont want to put in the effort then why should I?

The do update the map everyday to change it but the same assets are used... just moved around. So even though it is techniqually different, it feels the same.

Final thought
The gameplay that is there is very satisfying and fun. It's just a shame that that is all there is to it. I would love to see some actual content added here. If you see it on a sale go ahead and pick it up.

reviewText:
This game is easy to recommend, especially for those that don't have much time to invest in a game and just want something easy and fun to play.

Now the game is simple, what I mean by this is that the controls are straight forward and so is the main objective...race to the sun. The actual gameplay is a different factor, it can be VERY challenging in terms of actually making it far at least for me.

The obstacles you'll be facing start off very easy but then turn extremely challenging and a lot of the times very cheap. Especially playing through it the first time, you will not be able to predict how to dodge the objects which means this game forces you into death until you learn the patterns. This was a little bit of a let down only because I was looking forward to reaction time playing a role here not just guess and check.

To put it simple, you will die, you will die a lot. You will also try to avoid dieing but most of the time you'll have to do that in your second try.

Does this put a damper on the game play? To an extend yes, but it doesn't hurt the over all game. The game looks great, plays great and frankly has some awesome moments that remind me of Journey. I'm sure there will be quite a few people that will enjoy playing this game on and off between classes, work or on lazy days.

8.0/10 if you pick up during a sale and 7.5/10 if you purchase it at full price. Although the game is fun either way I feel that it didn't quite live up to the initial hype, but we did get a solid product!

reviewText: Reminds me of the old 3D vector racing games, you simply have to continue on chasing that sun in the distance without hitting obstacles. It also has some interesting mechanics such as your ship's power comes from solar energy, meaning if you spend too long in the dark you won't even need to worry about crashing, you will come to a complete halt. There are also pickups that extend the time it takes for the sun to set helping you keep your sun energy high and I enjoyed this teeter-totter style play where I frequently shift my eyes all around the screen hunting for pickups while trying to concentrate on my ship and the obstacles ahead. The maps are also generated daily and this keeps the replayability levels quite high whether you play for a few runs a day or hours at a time.\n\nIn short: I'd rate it around a 7. The graphics are simplistic but quite plain at the beginning which doesn't really appeal to me.

reviewText: Solar Powered spaceships riding at high speeds avoiding obstacles while going through rings (with pyramids in them, nonetheless). Sound familiar?\n\nRace The Sun is a cute little pickup-and-play game where you're basically an Arwing solar powered polygon ship thing trying to see how long you can survive. The scoring is kind of like Space Harrier, where the points increase at a fast rate as you go on and pickups give you a bonus, but with multipliers. The visuals are nice to look at, you'll want a watch" mode just to watch the ship fly around the area. The music is... "okay". It's forgettable but it's catchy and has a beat to it while you're playing. The game is simple. You avoid obstacles
date: pick up "Tris" which are little rings with triangular shapes in them
recommended: and picking up a set of them gives you x1 multiplier. The multiplier stacks up as you collect more sets. There's also other pickups but you unlock them as you level up. I like this approach. It's slow
hoursPlayed: easy and gives you a bit of an idea what the game is as you casually learn about the powerups instead of throwing them all at you with no explanation. The game has little tasks for you to fill out each play
voteText: in which you level up and unlock pickups and more stages as you complete them. Which is also nice. I only have a couple of problems with this game.\n\nFirst of all
helpfulPercent: I'm not sure but I think the game's trying to mock you. Saying how your "death was inevitable" and just discourages you through the game. I. ♥♥♥♥ing. Hate. This cliche. Remember in Portal
votesHelpful: where the robotic voice of GLaDOS taunts you throughout the game? Remember how charming and hilarious she was? Well the charm wore off quickly. After this game released
votesTotal: I've seen way too many games try to do this and sound "cool"
votesFunny: "edgy" or "funny." Both full retail games
commentsCount: indie games and flash games. It's getting annoying and it lacks originality. Second; (this one's minor) There's a lack of mod compatibility. Come on. I understand the game probably didn't have as high a budget as say
column16: Team Fortress 2 or Skyrim
column17: but for a game like this; Mods would be great. There's a section in the Steam Workshop for this game so why not? Custom music
column18: at least?The game's files you can't read under normal circumstances and some of them being "File" types. I might be stupid but I've modded before. I can't be the only one who think's the Corneria theme from Star Fox on the SNES would fit perfectly.\n\nOverall the game is... okay. It's fun to pick up and play but after a short while you'll get bored of it quickly. I can see myself coming back every now and then but after a few deaths there's nothing else to see. For $10

reviewText:
Race the Sun is definitely not a new game concept. However, this game takes an existing game concept and amplifies it to be so much better. It you have ever played Cubefield (it's free in-browser, go play it), this game is so much better. You race through a world that changes daily, dodging various obstacles: some that move, some that fall, some that tip over, some that race around, some that go over or under you, etc. The objective is to get as far as you can before the sun goes down or before you crash. The more challenges that you complete in game, the more upgrades you get that allow you to go further and further.

Definitely, a game worth trying; especially for a few bucks and to support inide development.
9/10

reviewText:
This game is pretty much a glorified flash/mobile game. Don't go in for much more. Buuuuuuuuuut... It has a few things going for it that set it apart from its legion of competitors.

Firstly, I love the visual style of this game. While they really could improve the pop-in at times, this game overall is incredibly striking and with the world being remixed every 24 hours you'll always have something new to see.

Secondly, as I mentioned the world is refreshed every 24 hours. This gives variety and keeps you seeing new stuff in the same way most runner" games do but having it refresh every 24 hours as opposed to after each death has a lot of appeal for me. It makes the leaderboards an even playing field with no-one reaching the top because they got a lucky world seed. It  also gives you a chance to learn the world a little without it being the same EVERY time you play. So every day you get a new chance to compete on an even playing field with new content which for me has been incredibly appealing.

The only issues I've run into are some pop-in problems at times with shadows propagating in front of objects that are yet to be visible. It's also very overpriced for a game of this type in my opinion. I got it on sale from GOG.com (the devs kindly provide a Steam key) and I would recommend waiting for a sale to purchase.

This is the first game that's ever gotten me to pay attention to leaderboards and try to be competitive (and the first time I've ever gotten into the top 1000 of a game
date: nevermind the heady heights of double digits I reached today). This game is head and shoulders above the others in it's genre and at the right price well worth a look.\n"

reviewText:
A combination of twitch reflexes, arcade fun and simplistic beauty.
Race the Sun challenges you to see how far you can go before the sun sets in your solar powered vehicle.
While easy on paper, obstacles from static objects to falling bombs stand in your way.

The perfect combination where you tell yourself 'just one more'.
But you know it's not the last.
This game is arcade heaven.

reviewText:
A game of its own, it's a really interesting racer(?). It does well with its sun system, that will keep your vehicle moving if you go fast enough and keep the sun upgrades nearby at all times. It has some decent challenges, but the FOV at times can really make dodging things in an instant a bit heckling. It's a decent game, however I can't say if it's worth the price, since I got it for free on Day 1 launch. That's up to you to decide.
Things to consider:
-Do I want a game with replay value?
-Do I want a game to boot up and play instantly when bored?
-Do I not mind the price?
-Does the workshop hold interest in me?

If you answered Yes" to at least two of these
hoursPlayed: and easy-to-learn controls. It can easily hold interest whilst bored
voteText: but don't expect to be playing this for hours at a time."

reviewText:
This is a little game where you fly with your little solar plane past little obstacles. Sounds simple? It isn't.
You will be trying to get past first region, after that second region and so on. This is what gives this a lot of replay value. Yes, the challenge.
Also, there is score that I personally don't care about because I have obstacles to not hit. I SUCK AT IT, OKAY? And some upgrades that can be quite useful on your journey of not hitting anything.
Did I mention that you have to collect floating stars so sun would stay up longer? Another layer of fun and challenge. Solar plane needs sun. No sun means no fun (it means you get frustrated and sad and this and that and thot...)

That music though, mmmmmm....

Lil' Sucky Gameplay to go with the review.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-Fmff9pgpbA

reviewText: Great little game. You fly your solar powered spaceship in an endless world trying to survive and get points. There's also a great modding community. With all the awesome maps people have made, you'll never run out of new things to do. It can get a little repetitive at times, but it's at least a few hours of great fun. There's also a leaderboard if you're in to that kind of thing. My biggest problem with the game is that I love the missions, and there aren't that many of them. I was able to do all the missions in about 2-3 hours. They have added three new offical maps since the release of the game, and none of them have changed the game too much. I'm hopping they either add new missions or some entirely new idea next.\nPick this game up. It's worth the $10.

reviewText: Solar Powered spaceships riding at high speeds avoiding obstacles while going through rings (with pyramids in them, nonetheless). Sound familiar?\n\nRace The Sun is a cute little pickup-and-play game where you're basically an Arwing solar powered polygon ship thing trying to see how long you can survive. The scoring is kind of like Space Harrier, where the points increase at a fast rate as you go on and pickups give you a bonus, but with multipliers. The visuals are nice to look at, you'll want a watch" mode just to watch the ship fly around the area. The music is... "okay". It's forgettable but it's catchy and has a beat to it while you're playing. The game is simple. You avoid obstacles
date: pick up "Tris" which are little rings with triangular shapes in them
recommended: and picking up a set of them gives you x1 multiplier. The multiplier stacks up as you collect more sets. There's also other pickups but you unlock them as you level up. I like this approach. It's slow
hoursPlayed: easy and gives you a bit of an idea what the game is as you casually learn about the powerups instead of throwing them all at you with no explanation. The game has little tasks for you to fill out each play
voteText: in which you level up and unlock pickups and more stages as you complete them. Which is also nice. I only have a couple of problems with this game.\n\nFirst of all
helpfulPercent: I'm not sure but I think the game's trying to mock you. Saying how your "death was inevitable" and just discourages you through the game. I. ♥♥♥♥ing. Hate. This cliche. Remember in Portal
votesHelpful: where the robotic voice of GLaDOS taunts you throughout the game? Remember how charming and hilarious she was? Well the charm wore off quickly. After this game released
votesTotal: I've seen way too many games try to do this and sound "cool"
votesFunny: "edgy" or "funny." Both full retail games
commentsCount: indie games and flash games. It's getting annoying and it lacks originality. Second; (this one's minor) There's a lack of mod compatibility. Come on. I understand the game probably didn't have as high a budget as say
column16: Team Fortress 2 or Skyrim
column17: but for a game like this; Mods would be great. There's a section in the Steam Workshop for this game so why not? Custom music
column18: at least?The game's files you can't read under normal circumstances and some of them being "File" types. I might be stupid but I've modded before. I can't be the only one who think's the Corneria theme from Star Fox on the SNES would fit perfectly.\n\nOverall the game is... okay. It's fun to pick up and play but after a short while you'll get bored of it quickly. I can see myself coming back every now and then but after a few deaths there's nothing else to see. For $10
column19: you can get the original Half-Life. I'd wait for this game to go on sale before you pick it up. It's the same problem Nidhogg has."

reviewText: Reminds me of the old 3D vector racing games, you simply have to continue on chasing that sun in the distance without hitting obstacles. It also has some interesting mechanics such as your ship's power comes from solar energy, meaning if you spend too long in the dark you won't even need to worry about crashing, you will come to a complete halt. There are also pickups that extend the time it takes for the sun to set helping you keep your sun energy high and I enjoyed this teeter-totter style play where I frequently shift my eyes all around the screen hunting for pickups while trying to concentrate on my ship and the obstacles ahead. The maps are also generated daily and this keeps the replayability levels quite high whether you play for a few runs a day or hours at a time.\n\nIn short: I'd rate it around a 7. The graphics are simplistic but quite plain at the beginning which doesn't really appeal to me.

reviewText: Not a bad 'endless runner' style flying game. If you get it cheap the time spent can be fun, and downloading mod-levels is an ok way of briefly extending the life of the mechanic. Feels like a tribute to old arcade games, and just like some of them, it fails to leave an impression worth revisiting outside of nostalgic memory.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm going to dissent. At the time of writing, 95% of reviewers have recommended this game. I won't.

It is a minimalist racing game that tests the reflexes. It is well done within its context. It is hard to find fault in what is implemented.

The issue is, well, what is implemented amounts to not-very-much. I played it a few times after buying it, and haven't touched it since nor had any inclination to. Once you've played it a few times then that's it, you've exhausted the variety of the game - there's nothing left to discover other than how far you can get into the game. You'll never uncover anything new in terms of the gameplay. You just might see a few more types of object to dodge.

Sure, the layout of each level changes every 24 hours. Sure, some people have created quite a variety of levels in the workshop. However, it all boils down to the same very simple game - dodge until you die. It's really a mini-game and as such I can't recommend it as a £6.99 (or ~$10) purchase.

reviewText:
I want to recommend this game.

But I cant. The developers, despite what I'm sure were good intentions, have made the game - if not  impossible  to play, then at least annoying to the extreme. Flippfly appears to have little regard for player imput, or indeed, play choice in how to play the game. They have implemented sounds that, if you find them annoying as I do, and want to turn them off - too bad. You'll have to turn off all game sound to mute the whiring, overheated computer fan sound of your engine.

But I can deal with that. No, the reason for the negative review is the breaking of the game by compulsory community maps. I'm all for community participation in games, but when you are  forced  to play maps off the workshop, the game becomes frustrating and broken. They are either overcomplicated, unintuitive, or simply completely broken - one places you in what I imagine the creator was a cinematic" view
date: which has the kind of serious flaw of completely dislocating you from your ships position
recommended: resulting in crashes where you thought you shouldn't have been.\n\nDespite continual complaints against this forced participation and lack of player adjustablity
hoursPlayed: Flippfly has refused to even acknowledge there is a problem. If and when they fix these issues
voteText: I'll more than happily recommend this game to any-and-everyone. Until then

reviewText:
Race The Sun
Rating: 8 / 10

Beat the sun by racing your ship through the obstacles and picking up stuff to make you jump, go faster and enhance your score with only one goal: to keep flying.

Minimalistic racer that keeps you starting over and over again after you hit another object. You always start at the beginning of the level (resets after 24 hours) so after a while you know where to go and to pick up your powerups. The races are fairly short but that makes you try it over and over again. Levelling up is also pretty ok as you get 3 goals to achieve and you have to get 4 goals to get to the next level. You then get additional stuff like the ability to jump or double jump, better multipliers and enhancements to your ship like magnets to pick up powerups. Pretty decently done and I definitely recommend the game to all!

So get it and race!

reviewText:
I picked this up on a free day.

A simple yet mesmerising race type game.
I wasnt sure I liked it at first some of the leveling up was hard and detracted from the fun of the race, but once you get to level 25 you miss the goals.

I keep coming back to play this since the script generated maps change on a daily basis. I am quite enjoying it and some of the user generated levels are quite a realaxing fun change from the sphincter clenching fun of the race.
It feels simple enough while generating many hours of enjoyment. I would recommend this on sale.

reviewText:
I don't really understand the point of this game. Only purpose of this game is to get a higher score on a daily changing leaderboard and complete specifics tasks to gain levels, but that's it.

All levels are randomized on a daily basis, so you can't rely on your memory. It gets tedious and boring after couple of hours. Music is bland, forgettable with no variation. Graphics are too simplistic. Controls have a heavy input lag (slightly gets better with an upgrade).

The way upgrades are given out is not really rewarding despite needing to complete challenges. New challenges are only given out if you complete the previous ones and die... so you don't actually want to race fast and far, but rather do tedious tasks and get all upgrades.

reviewText:
Do you like mindless repetition? Then you'll love this game! I was bored to tears within 15 minutes, and I've tried the game a couple of times since then, but there simply isn't any content. Or rather, there is, but it's hidden behind a wall of perfection you will never see. Let me explain:

Race The Sun is an infinite runner in the most vanilla sense of the genre. Press start > move left and right > get as many score multipliers as you can > run in to something or go too slow > repeat from the beginning. The problem with this model is that there is no progression; in a little over an hour of gameplay I've seen Region 3 twice and, of course, Region 1 every single time I've died (which must have been 60+ times). You will be bored to tears by Region 1, but you'll be forced to play it over, and over, and over again.

There is a levelling system, but it takes a ridiculously long time to level up, as they require events during the level that are down to pure luck as to whether you can pull them off. The levels may be \procedurally generated" to some degree
date: but you will the same chunks of obsticles over and over
recommended: and while the location may be different
hoursPlayed: the order is the same. The moment you make some progress and feel curiosity for the first time in a while
voteText: you\'ll die and get sent back to Repetition Land. The price is absurd for what free mobile games do better
helpfulPercent: and the artsy style will not be enough after your fifteenth death."

reviewText:
Race the Sun is a fun little game that acts as a good reactionary trainer and the art style reminds me of Star Fox.

The downside of the game is that there is only one level.  But the upside is that a new version of the level is procedurally generated every day.  This is refreshing feature that can make me come back to the game to test my reflex skills.

I like the minimalist art style and that the level is broken down into several regions with increasing difficulty. What I don’t like is the simplicity of the gameplay; there needs to be more pick-ups, ship abilities and controller buttons to press.

With the Steam Workshop there might be some cool user levels to add variety.  But most people will get bored of this game quick, including me.  If you want to play this game you should wait for a bargain sale because you will probably only get a couple hours of fun.

Race the Sun is a good game, but it’s one of those PC games best served on a tablet to pass the time.  If this game gets touch screen support I will recommend it because the simplistic game mechanics can be justified.

reviewText:
tl;dr - Audio Version: https://soundcloud.com/econaelgaming/review-racethesun

Race the Sun is a beautifully crafted game with an appealing aesthetic.
Sadly the great polish of game mechanics doesn't bring a similar level of polish of the game's design.

Race the Sun is an endless runner with an infinitely wide world and it disincentivizes lateral movement by making it dangerous.
The theme is that you're steering a solar powered glider and the sun is going down quickly, making shadows longer.
There are pickups that push the sun back up and give you a speed boost.
These pickups have a big ray that goes into the sky, showing where they are, but the draw distance is so low, that when you see them, you need to instantly do a full steer in that direction to get it and if there's an obstacle close to you forcing you to stay put for a second, you'll miss it.
There is only 1 level that is freshly generated once a day.
These things coupled together, mean that optimal play includes trial & error to find the optimal path that connects as many of said powerups and memorization of that path.

The game uses a progression via small achievements, similar to games such as Jetpack Joyride and these achievements unlock new game mechanics (powerups, game modes etc.).
Gating content behind achievements always means that most of those achievements are boring, so as to not hide a big percentage of content from players, so the game has lots of Reach X amount of cumulative distance traveled" or "Crash X times" achievements. On top of that
date: the text upon reaching an achievement is a nihilistic "meh
recommended:
achievements suck anyway and you're stupid for caring about points" type of "humorous" text.

I unlocked a harder game mode that has repeated the same ~20 seconds of level over and over. I believe it would repeat endlessly. Not appealing.

So it's still very beautiful and the controls feel nice
hoursPlayed: but there's not a lot of game behind it."

reviewText:
Love this game. I'd go as far as calling it strategic but not to the point you can memorize every region and breeze through, even with a general idea of the landscape, each run will bring a new obstacle you may not have encountered before.
This game provides a challenge without being incredibly difficult to pick up on, and when it starts to get intense, the soundtrack will pick up and all the narrow misses will send a jolt of adrenaline through your body.

With all this being said, I have encountered the corrupt save file bug, not once, but twice. Both seemingly after computer restarts (while game was shut down and not active in anyway).

For this alone, I cannot recommend this game to anyone as this is a huge bug that get's rid of any progress you have made. This happened the day I bought the game, I can't imagine having played it for a week and then lost all of my upgrades and power ups which change the whole dynamic of the game.

Until this bug is fixed, you are essentially playing a game that resets every day.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game. I really did. It just feels lacking in too many areas for me to recommend.

My first complaint is how slow the game feels. Right off the bat you might think I'm crazy as the game seems to make you think it's all about speed. However, the slow, drifty turning, the painful wait times between regions and the floatiness in the air seems to slow the game down dramatically. Try playing something like Super Hexagon, which has very snappy, precise controls and you'll see what I mean. The worst contributor to the pace of the game, though, is the time it takes between dying and starting a new game. Everything about this game tells me it's trying to be a fast, addictive game that players can lose themselves in for hours on end. When I die, I should immediately be playing again in less than 1 second. The way it is now, the game shows a death animation for a second, then shows the score screen with some achievements for another second, then goes to an intro screen with a quote that is displayed long enough to read, the player swoops in, then there is still a few seconds before the player reaches any obstacles they need to avoid. Most of this could be cut out and the game would be so much more playable!

The game doesn't have many new interestng mechanics, either. Tiny Wings (another achievement-based arcade game with a near-identical plot) had it's physics-based jumping mechanic. Time Surfers added to the Tiny Wings formula by adding the time-reversing mechanic. This just feels like a driftier, slower, blander version of cubefield, a flash game made 4 years ago. The only new idea I haven't seen anywhere else is the mechanic where flying in shadows slows you down, which is essentially adding extra danger to the already-existing obstacles instead of introducing something new for the player to actively do. Everything else in the game seems to be following the achievement-based mobile game formula.

I'm typically a gameplay-focused guy who doesn't care about visuals or sound, but I found them getting in the way of my enjoyment of this game. I understand the developers were going for a minimalist look, only using colors for pickups, but the environment just comes off as bland and unattractive. It just looks like default diffuse Unity shaders. The lighting effects where the shadows grow longer as the sun goes down is a neat mechanic that combines the art/environment with the gameplay, but it also highlights another problem: the draw distance. I often ran into situations where large objects would pop into view way later than I should have been able to see them, especially after the sun was starting to set. Again, I understand that the game is supposed to become more challenging as the sun is setting, making it harder for the player to see and making the game more tense as a result. However, I only felt cheated as I couldn't tell the distance between an unavoidable horizontal object that popped in too late and a shadow. Adding color to the environment would probably have helped this immensely, but instead the gray of the objects and the gray of the shadows just blend together too much.

Moving into sound, I was turned off by the music after only a few playthroughs. Every game plays the exact same song! The little jingle that plays when you beat a region is, in my opinion, very annoying and even now I hear it ringing in my ears. Looking at Super Hexagon again, there were 2 songs for each of the 3" difficulties and the starting point in each song was moved around so they sounded different each time you played. It sounded like there was a lot more variation then there was
date: adding extra life to the already amazing soundtrack. This game's song started off kind of flat and its repetition only made worse over time.\n\nGoing back to mechanics
recommended: I want to discuss the procedural generation. I think part of the pitch for this game was to have a new procedurally generated level every day so players can compete for the top score on that specific level. When the next day comes around
hoursPlayed: the winner of the top score for the previous day will remain the victor for eternity and everyone gets to compete again on a new level from a clean slate. This concept sounds very interesting and I commend the developers for trying it
voteText: but I don't think it worked in practice. If this is a skill/reflex based game

Does memorizing the optimal path in the first region really give the player an edge after surviving 10 regions in a row? Is it even possible to memorize the optimal path through the first 5 regions and remember your score after each one to see if that path was really optimal? Is there a point in doing so if the game is going to reset in a day anyway? What I'm getting at here that I don't see the point in keeping the level the same each day. I would rather have  each level procedurally generated every time I start a new game. It's supposed to be skill based anyway

At my low skill level where I'm dying consistently in Region 3
